p.s: Amir Kapoor is the protagonist of the play Disgraced, Scene 3.
He is in his early fourties and lives in a spacious apartment in New York's upper east side with his wife Emily.
He works as a corporate lawyer at a jewishJewish lawfirm.
Amir is described to be and American-born male with south-asian origin who lives an affluent lifestyle.
Despite his violent appearance in scene three, Amir tries to control his anger.
In order to avoid further development of the conflict, he asks Jory to get out (p. 73, l. 3).
This reveals that Amir seeks to avoid unneccessaryunnecessary conflict and the use of violence.
This conflict-avoidant attitude is underlined by Amir's decency.
The regret Amir shows after beating his wife is very apparent (p. 74, l. 15).
This proves that in spite of his ruthless act of violence, Amir does not lack human decency.
The beating of his wife proves Amir to be hypocritical.
Even though Amir criticises the Quran for advocating the beating of one's wife earlier in the play, he does exactly that.
This reveals that Amir is haunted by his strict Muslim upbringing and does not manage to refrain from the violence he seeks to avoid.
Furthermore, Amir's identity is duplicious.
Much like his hypocritical act, Amir spits in Isaac's face (l. 40).
This gesture refers to the story Amir tells earlier in the play, where his mother spat in his face because he exchanged notes with a Jewish girl, who would not be accepted in their Muslim household.
These hypocrysieshypocrisies and duplicities all show an inner-conflict of Amir.
The primary source of anger, which Amir apparently shows in this scene, is the resentment he built up in the course of his life.
Amir is very resentful because usually well-meaning people discriminate him for his Muslim identity which he tries to obscure.
Isaac, who has a limited understanding of Islam, insults Amir as an animal (p. 73, l. 1).
Therefore, even those who are superficially intrigued by Islam turn out to be Islamophobic and confrontconfronts Amir.
Amir's relationship with Emily is characterised with trust.
Even though Jory is sure that she saw Emily and Isaac kiss, Amir believes Emily's excuse and sees Jory's act as an attempt to destroy (p. 72, l. 18) his marriage.
This shows that Amir trusts Emily regardless of the situation or circumstances.
In contrast, Amir's relationship with Isaac is characterised with hate and disgust.
The entire conflict revolves around Isaac cheating on his wife and the polarised opinions Amir and Isaac share on Islam.
They both provocate the conflict to get physical (p. 72, l. 32) even before Emily concedes that she is having an affair with Isaac.
Hence, Amir and Isaac's relationship is toxic and hostile.
In summary, Amir's character is shaped by his strong resentment and duplicious identity, which form an inner-conflict that controls his emotions.
